SEARCH
Package danogl.gui

Interface WindowController

All Known Implementing Classes:
GameGUIComponent
public interface WindowController
Provides control and info regarding the game.
Author:
Dan Nirel

  • Method Details

    • closeWindow

      void closeWindow()
      Exit the game.

    • resetGame

      void resetGame()
      Reset the game, as if it was just opened.

    • messages

      MessageHandler messages()
      Returns an object responsible for handling logging and messages

    • showMessageBox

      @Deprecated default void showMessageBox(String msg)
      Deprecated.
      If you know you want a message-box, prefer MessageHandler.showMessage(String, EnumSet), with the call messages().showMessage(msg, OutputMode.MSG_BOX) . More generally, to show a message with a desired level of urgency, use MessageHandler.showMessage(String,MsgLevel), for example messages().showMessage(msg, MsgLevel.ERROR) .
      Open a message box. While the message box is open, the game is paused.
      See Also:
      • messages()

    • openYesNoDialog

      boolean openYesNoDialog(String msg)
      Open a dialog window that shows the provided prompt and then asks for yes or no. While the dialog is open, the game is paused.
      Returns:
      true if the user chose yes, false if they chose no.

    • getTimeScale

      double getTimeScale()
      The current time-scale of the game. See setTimeScale(float).

    • setTimeScale

      void setTimeScale(float value)
      Sets the game's time-scale. A value of 1 is normal speed, a value in the range (0,1) is slow-motion. A value over 1 is fast. A value of exactly 0 is not recommended - it might provide edge-cases for some of your classes. To pause the game, see setPauseButton(int) method in this interface.

      A negative value is technically supported, but you'd better be sure that your own GameObjects actually support a negative deltaTime parameter.

      The deltaTime parameter supplied in the update methods is effectively the actual time since the previous frame, multiplied by whatever you put here.

    • getWindowDimensions

      Vector2 getWindowDimensions()
      The window's dimensions in pixels

    • setTargetFramerate

      void setTargetFramerate(int targetFramerate)
      The idle-time (sleeping-time) between frames will be adjusted to try and hit the specified targetFramerate.

      A higher targetFramerate will make the game smoother, if this framerate is indeed achievable given the resources your game consumes each frame.

      A targetFramerate too high will cause the game to never sleep, and thus the time between two frames will be exactly the time it took to update and render the frame. This will result in a non-consistent framerate, and will also hog more of the CPU's time. The deltaTime parameter of the update method might be very inconsistent.

      A low targetFramerate will assure that the game runs in a consistent pace (which might or might not be important, depending on the application) and consumes less resources, at the cost of a choppier experience.

    • setPauseButton

      void setPauseButton(int keyFromKeyEvent)
      Sets a key to pause and unpause the game (prevent update calls). By default, pausing is disabled (the game cannot be paused). Call this method to allow pausing.
      Parameters:
      keyFromKeyEvent - A constant from KeyEvent, or -1 to specify that pausing should be disabled.

    • setExitButton

      void setExitButton(int keyFromKeyEvent)
      Sets a key to exit the game. By default, the escape key will exit the game.
      Parameters:
      keyFromKeyEvent - A constant from KeyEvent, or -1 to specify that no key should exit the game.

    • setMouseCursor

      void setMouseCursor(Renderable renderable, Vector2 dimensions, Vector2 offset)
      Sets a custom mouse cursor.
      Parameters:
      renderable - the renderable to be rendered at the mouse position. a value of null makes the cursor invisible.
      dimensions - cursor size, in pixels
      offset - offset of the renderable relative to the mouse position. For example, an offset of (0,0) means the top-left corner of the supplied renderable will be at the mouse position. An offset of dimensions.mult(-0.5f) will align the renderable's center with the mouse position.

    • getMouseCursor

      Renderable getMouseCursor()
      Returns the current Renderable that serves as a mouse cursor

    • getMouseCursorDimensions

      Vector2 getMouseCursorDimensions()
      Returns the current dimensions of the mouse cursor
